recipies.name: Chicken adobo
recipies.description: A classic filipino favorite food made with chicked, pepper, soy sauce, vinegar.

ingredients.name: brown sugar (optional, for hint of sweetness)

instructions.description: In a large bowl, combine the chicken pieces with soy sauce and half of the minced garlic. Marinate for at least 30 minutes, but preferably 1-3 hours in the refrigerator for better flavor.
Heat the cooking oil in a large skillet or pot over medium-high heat. Add the chopped onion and the remaining garlic, sautéing until fragrant and the onions are translucent, about 2-3 minutes.
Add the marinated chicken pieces to the skillet, reserving the marinade for later. Brown the chicken on all sides, about 5-7 minutes.
Pour the reserved marinade, vinegar, and water into the skillet with the chicken. Add the bay leaves, whole peppercorns, and brown sugar if using. Stir to combine
Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat to low. Cover and let it simmer for about 30-40 minutes, or until the chicken is cooked through and tender. Stir occasionally to prevent sticking.
Taste the sauce and adjust seasoning with salt and pepper if needed. You can also add more soy sauce or vinegar to suit your taste preference.
Once the chicken is done, remove the bay leaves.Serve the chicken adobo hot over steamed rice, garnished with chopped green onions.

recipies.name: Pork sinigang
recipies.description: A classic filipino food made with pork, kangkong, okra, eggplant, tomato.

instructions.description: In a large bowl, combine the chicken pieces with soy sauce and half of the minced garlic. Marinate for at least 30 minutes, but preferably 1-3 hours in the refrigerator for better flavor.Wash and prepare all the vegetables. Peel and cut the radish, eggplant, and optionally, taro. Quarter the tomatoes and onion. Wash and trim the green chili peppers. Rinse and chop the kangkong or sitaw

In a large pot, add the pork pieces and pour in enough water to cover the meat. Bring to a boil over medium heat, skimming off any scum that rises to the surface. Let it boil for 5-10 minutes, then discard the water and rinse the pork to remove impurities. This step helps ensure a clean broth.
Return the pork to the pot and add the 6 cups of water. Bring to a boil, then lower the heat and simmer for about 30-45 minutes or until the pork is tender.
Add the quartered onion and tomatoes to the pot. Let it cook for about 5 minutes until the tomatoes soften.
Add the eggplant, okra, and green chili peppers. Continue to simmer for another 5-7 minutes.

Pour in the sinigang mix or fresh tamarind pulp. Stir well and let it simmer for another 3-5 minutes. Adjust the sourness to your taste.Season with fish sauce or salt to taste. Start with 1-2 tablespoons and adjust as needed.
Add the kangkong or sitaw last. Let it cook for another 2-3 minutes until the greens are just wilted but still vibrant.

ingredients.name: fresh basil leaves, chopped(optional for garnish)

instructions.description: Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil. Add the spaghetti and cook according to the package instructions until al dente. Typically, this takes about 8-10 minutes. Drain the spaghetti and set aside. You can toss it with a bit of olive oil to prevent sticking.

While the pasta is cooking, heat the olive oil in a large skillet or saucepan over medium heat.Add the chopped onion and sauté until it becomes translucent, about 5 minutes.Add the minced garlic and sauté for another minute until fragrant.

f you're making a meat sauce, add the ground beef or pork to the skillet. Cook, breaking it apart with a wooden spoon, until it is browned and cooked through. This should take about 5-7 minutes. Drain any excess fat if necessary.
Stir in the canned crushed tomatoes or tomato sauce and tomato paste. Mix well to combine.

Add the dried oregano, basil, thyme, and sugar (if using). Season with salt and pepper to taste. Bring the sauce to a simmer and let it cook for about 15-20 minutes, stirring occasionally, to allow the flavors to meld together. If the sauce becomes too thick, you can add a bit of water to reach your desired consistency.
Add the cooked spaghetti to the sauce, tossing to coat the pasta evenly with the sauce. Alternatively, you can serve the sauce over the spaghetti on individual plates
